posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
We‚Äôre thinking about redesigning our practice bot‚Äôs elevator this summer so that it uses continuous rigging, rather than cascade .   Mostly this is just for practice, but we‚Äôre also looking to see if a continuous elevator is any easier to build or control, especially with more than 2 stages.

We‚Äôve never built a continuous elevator before, so I‚Äôm looking for some OPEX before we start.  Similar to this previous thread , can anyone offer advice on the following?

Our team values reliability, and I saw too many teams with stripped elevator belts this year).  For team that used HTD Belt rigging this year - what worked and what didn‚Äôt?

Our team values reliability, and I saw too many teams with stripped elevator belts this year).  For team that used HTD Belt rigging this year - what worked and what didn‚Äôt?

My thinking is dyneema rigging is cheaper and more reliable, however driving rope is a challenge.  The most popular method seems to be wrapping multiple times over a spool made from 1 to 2" OD tubing (example from team 111 below).  How many wraps do people use?  How do you accommodate the wraps moving left and right?  Has anyone tried eliminating the fixed anchor in the middle of the spool?  (That would reduce the ‚Äúwidth‚Äù of spool required, but it would need the tension to be consistent to avoid slipping). image 994√ó750 109 KB

My thinking is dyneema rigging is cheaper and more reliable, however driving rope is a challenge.  The most popular method seems to be wrapping multiple times over a spool made from 1 to 2" OD tubing (example from team 111 below).  How many wraps do people use?  How do you accommodate the wraps moving left and right?  Has anyone tried eliminating the fixed anchor in the middle of the spool?  (That would reduce the ‚Äúwidth‚Äù of spool required, but it would need the tension to be consistent to avoid slipping). image 994√ó750 109 KB

image 994√ó750 109 KB

image 994√ó750 109 KB

Another option which might package better is to loop the rope back and forth between two counter-rotating spools  (examples from @clydefrog88 and @Programming4907 below). This way the rope doesn‚Äôt walk left or right when winching.   What are the drawbacks with this approach? image 1920√ó1440 216 KB image 1920√ó2560 505 KB

This way the rope doesn‚Äôt walk left or right when winching.   What are the drawbacks with this approach? image 1920√ó1440 216 KB image 1920√ó2560 505 KB

I understand that losing tension is what causes rope winches to tangle or slip.  What‚Äôs the best method to keep both ends of the rope tensioned?   Is a ratcheting drum anchor good enough, or do you need a tension spring too?

I understand that losing tension is what causes rope winches to tangle or slip.  What‚Äôs the best method to keep both ends of the rope tensioned?   Is a ratcheting drum anchor good enough, or do you need a tension spring too?

What other gotchas / advice to you have for working with continuous elevators and/or Dyneema rigging?

What other gotchas / advice to you have for working with continuous elevators and/or Dyneema rigging?

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
nuclearnerd:

Another option which might package better is to loop the rope back and forth between two counter-rotating spools

Ours weren‚Äôt counter-rotating.  We looked at the counter-rotating idea and didn‚Äôt like how the rope rubs on itself.

The method we used still involves having circular grooves in each pulley (not spiral) and then we offset the top and bottom spools by half a groove so the rope moves over by one full groove from top to bottom to top again.  That means the rope always spools off the same points on the spools.

Ideally you want the connection point on the elevator to be directly in-line with these spool-off points.

nuclearnerd:

Our team values reliability, and I saw too many teams with stripped elevator belts this year). For team that used HTD Belt rigging this year - what worked and what didn‚Äôt?

We used cascade also but with belts and custom machined UHMW pulleys for moving the cascade stage ‚Äì it held up really well. We used this belt specifically: Gates LL5MR09 Belt . If we had chose to rig it continuous-style, I didn‚Äôt see anything this year that would give me pause using the same parts in that sort of configuration. We tried with dyneema early in the season and it stretched some ‚Äì I‚Äôm definitely a belt-convert for elevators after this season.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
Programming4907:

The method we used still involves having circular grooves in each pulley (not spiral) and then we offset the top and bottom spools by half a groove so the rope moves over by one full groove from top to bottom to top again. That means the rope always spools off the same points on the spools.

That looks very similar to how some building elevators are rigged .  Did you have any issues with this approach?  Would you do it again the same way in future?

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
nuclearnerd:

many wraps do people use?

3 was enough for us (i.e., the minimum when the rope for that spool was ‚Äúfully deployed‚Äù). The capstan equation is your friend here.

That said, tensioning rope that constantly ‚Äústretches‚Äù is annoying, and we are trying a belt for the offseason.

nuclearnerd:

How do you accommodate the wraps moving left and right? Has anyone tried eliminating the fixed anchor in the middle of the spool?

We tied the rope through a hole on the side of the spool, like the 111 picture, but a much thinner spool, and imagine a small hole in the plates that support the tube shaft. The tube was driven from outside of these rope retaining plates. We didn‚Äôt bother to accommodate wraps moving, and were only punished by that if we lost tension in the rope, since our pulley was thin enough it couldn‚Äôt walk very far left or right.

If you have space for it, a turnbuckle in line with the spring is nice, since it makes it much easier to retie the elevator if the rope stretches enough that the spring is useless, or if the rope comes off of a pulley and it is too taut to easily get back on.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Caveat: I have never built nor been part of a team that built a multi-stage elevator; just a few theoretical issues I can see.

I have nothing on stripped timing belts.

The biggest disadvantage I see with rope (or smooth belt) is that unless you have an anchored point somewhere, you can‚Äôt reliably use the position of your drive pulley as a proxy for the elevator height; you‚Äôll need a few limit switches at a minimum to do calibration/recalibration.  With cascade, an anchor is usually easy because travel is short; not with continuous, unless you do something with a crazy long constant force spring.  BTW, you can find crazy long low near-constant force springs in tape measures. tapeMeasureStringPot 1920√ó360 60.4 KB That‚Äôs an inch and a half of KoP chassis end plate, a bit of aluminum bar, a few machine screws/nuts, a cheap (Lowes IIRC) red tape measure, a black Radio Shack volume knob, and a blue 10-turn potentiometer held together with aluminum bracket we tried to use as a string pot on our 2015 single stage elevator. We didn‚Äôt use this in competition FWIW, but it was our inability to build it into something reliable, so perhaps it might inspire in this context.  It was definitely our most ambitious sensor up to that time.

tapeMeasureStringPot 1920√ó360 60.4 KB

tapeMeasureStringPot 1920√ó360 60.4 KB

An advantage of the multiple wraps (counter rotating or not) for your drive pulley is more grip on the pulleys for a given tension, reducing the issue with number 2.  Counter-rotating has the slight advantage of introducing less differential in twist as you go, compared to just multiple wraps.  For multiple wraps without counter, why not just do slightly bigger pulley and lower gearing?

While of course you want constant force springs to reduce the amount of work your motors need to do, it seems that the easiest way to maintain tension is to have those springs be intentionally either over- or under- tensioned both under load and non-load condtions.  The choice will likely depend on your start-of-match and end-of-match configurations; make those easy!

Again, I haven‚Äôt done this, but unless you need high tension in those lines, you might want to try natural fibers as well as artificial, because most artificial fibers tend to be less grippy.  Same goes with the pulleys.  Can you use a grippier material, or coat it in something that is?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
The spring is there to account for the changing tension that results from unequal / uneven tension as the dyneema wraps over itself.

If you use a continuous tension system (the side by side spools that you showed) or if you use the drum method (some teams print a large OD spiral that the rope wraps on to prevent it wrapping over itself) you can do without the spring.

The best tensioning method we‚Äôve used definitely involves ratchets.

Dyneema needs to be checked regularly for chafe points until you‚Äôre confident your system doesn‚Äôt have any.  It‚Äôs easy to quickly wear through it.

Also, regarding stretch, dyneema doesn‚Äôt really stretch once you‚Äôve set it.  So let‚Äôs get technical.  High tech lines have ‚Äòcreep‚Äô.

Here‚Äôs a great article on it:

426.13 KB

Most of the dyneema we use in robotics is the lower quality non-pre-stretched versions.  Notice the quoted creep rates.

At 20% load and .1%/month creep rate, your average run of robot dyneema (let‚Äôs call it 15 feet) would creep .18 inches - in a month.

What most robotics teams call ‚Äòstretch‚Äô is the knots working in and setting under time.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
I need to play with my capstan elevator more before I weigh in. From my limited testing, the capstans demand more rigidity in the elevator structure than a spooling winch. I owe everyone a big update this summer.

Tom_Line:

What most robotics teams call ‚Äòstretch‚Äô is the knots working in and setting under time.

Great Product

Good rope tools and splices are the way to go. Splices settle in too, but (anecdotally) less than a figure 8 double loop or a bowline.

posts.cooked:
nuclearnerd:

How many wraps do people use

As large of a diameter as reasonable. Larger diameter results in a lower fleet angle which makes things easier. Extra diameter does require more reduction, but its a small price to pay for making the rigging just behave better.

nuclearnerd:

How do you accommodate the wraps moving left and right

If your fleet angle is small enough, it should just behave. Helical grooves can be added to the spool to improve spooling behavior with larger fleet angles or in other suboptimal rigging setups and I generally recommend adding them anyways.

nuclearnerd:

(That would reduce the ‚Äúwidth‚Äù of spool required, but it would need the tension to be consistent to avoid slipping).

I mean you can do this, but I‚Äôd rather just tie/clamp the rope off on the spool and never have to worry about if my tension is perfect or not.

nuclearnerd:

I understand that losing tension is what causes rope winches to tangle or slip. What‚Äôs the best method to keep both ends of the rope tensioned? Is a ratcheting drum anchor good enough, or do you need a tension spring too?

A spring is required because spools have a fleet angle, resulting in the elevator travel not quite being equal to the rope being unwound. I‚Äôve tensioned rope successfully with as little as a single (stiff) spring and a clamp-off point, but other features can be added to make tensioning easier.

Tom_Line:

Most of the dyneema we use in robotics is the lower quality non-pre-stretched versions. Notice the quoted creep rates.

DM20 is also a thing which experiences significantly less creep than SK78/older dyneema fibers. Its a little hard to source in non-boat sizes and quantities, but it will cut down on the maintenance required.

GeeTwo:

While of course you want constant force springs to reduce the amount of work your motors need to do, it seems that the easiest way to maintain tension is to have those springs be intentionally either over- or under- tensioned both under load and non-load condtions. The choice will likely depend on your start-of-match and end-of-match configurations; make those easy!

I personally recommend avoiding CF springs on elevators. They are incredibly obnoxious to work with with them being hard (and dangerous) to install, their performance varying significantly depending on how recently you have greased them, and them wearing out quickly due to FRC teams using them outside of specifications. And they don‚Äôt even speed up your elevator that much as inertia is a much more significant factor in elevator performance.

nuclearnerd:

What other gotchas / advice to you have for working with continuous elevators and/or Dyneema rigging?

There‚Äôs another way of rigging continuous elevators that not too many teams know about but imo is better in many cases than the standard way of rigging elevators. image 1238√ó872 47.7 KB

image 1238√ó872 47.7 KB

image 1238√ó872 47.7 KB

For the small price of spooling twice the amount of rope as usual on one spool, you can mount the spool to the side of the elevator rather than in front or behind, get a 2:1 reduction, power both sides of the elevator, eliminate any synching issues typically associated with powering both sides by using one rope, (knots/clamps not tied perfectly even, hex shaft torsion), reduce the elevator to only one tension point and point of maintaince, and keep all tensioning equiptment at the bottom of the elevator rather than on the carriage.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
nuclearnerd:

Our team values reliability, and I saw too many teams with stripped elevator belts this year). For team that used HTD Belt rigging this year - what worked and what didn‚Äôt?

We used PolyBelt belts on our elevator this year and couldn‚Äôt be happier with the performance. Some will say that you absolutely must use the WCP belt or else an official Gates belt but my experience this season is that is not the case. The Polybelt belt is cheaper, is kevlar reinforced, and can be purchased by the foot.

so I‚Äôm looking for some OPEX

As someone who works for OPEX , today I learned a new abbreviation.

posts.name: Christoforus Cedric Kurniawan
posts.cooked:
Our team used a continuous rope lift this year, heavily copying the Rusthounds RI3D . We had 4 different spools, 2 to pull the lift up, and 2 to pull the lift down. The ‚Äúup‚Äù and ‚Äúdown‚Äù spools are wrapped in opposite directions.

I would say the most important thing about doing a lift in this style is to have all of your corresponding pulleys match. For example, we had  2 pulleys pulling the carriage up, and both had to be spooled in the same direction. To keep proper tension, each spool also had to have the EXACT same number of wraps and must not overlap. Overlapping spools would create uneven diameters, leading to different amounts of rope being pulled ‚Üí uneven tension. The spools pulling down on the carriage also had the same idea, but were wrapped in the opposite direction when compared to the ‚Äúup‚Äù spools.

For tensioning, our down spools were attached to a REV turnbuckle, which was attached to a spring, which was attached to the bottom rail of the carriage. The up spools were wrapped around a screw that had a REV Shaft Collar that was just big enough for a #10 screw. When wrapped correctly, a simple tightening of the screw allowed us to quickly tension the rope.

Another important thing to consider is the friction between stages. We used REV MAXLift bearing blocks, and had some issues with manufacturing tolerance which led to lots of friction between out stages. To ensure the carriage moved first, we added a piece of surgical tubing to help pull the carriage up. Ideally, a CF spring would probably be better. IMG_6441 1536√ó2048 200 KB

IMG_6441 1536√ó2048 200 KB

IMG_6441 1536√ó2048 200 KB

The cad is not fully up-to-date, so spools aren‚Äôt fully CADed, but the pulleys are in the right spot. Our spools were a piece of VersaRoller between 2 versahubs.

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

posts.name: Tom Praisner
posts.cooked:
We used a pre-grooved spool with internal rigging using SDS elevator blocks.  Was really robust and relatively simple.  I really like the idea @clydefrog88 has to use a capstan drive for Dyneema-based rigging.:

posts.name: Elin Kim
posts.cooked:
For question number 1: Our team (694) created a single stage internally rigged belt elevator (inspired by 4414) for the first time this season, and there were many things we learned. Though it single staged, most thing below still applies if this were a multistage elevator. Benefits

Due to how the belts are in between the tubings, it saved quite a bit of space.

I have never experienced creating elevators with ropes, but if the belt is tensioned properly in the beginning, you will only have to retention is once or twice during the season.

Very reliable. Although the belt tension was not the best throughout the season, the elevator never failed to function during matches (even when the spools broke).

Challenges

The spools inside broke a few times, but this is preventable with strong material and print settings. This was a bit challenging to replace, especially during competitions. Other than this issue (which is preventable), we had no other major problems. We printed the spools in PCABS with low infill, but many teams seem to use CF-nylon.

Rigging can be difficult, but this can easily be changed with thoughtful designs.

Since there are slots on the tubings, it takes some time to manufacture.

We didn‚Äôt have issues with the costs of belts because it was a single stage elevator, but if you have more than one stage, the belts are a bit expensive.

Thank you for the thread. I learned a lot about elevators using ropes!

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked:
nuclearnerd:

I saw too many teams with stripped elevator belts

This is the first I have ever heard about a stripped belt in an elevator

nuclearnerd:

For team that used HTD Belt rigging this year - what worked and what didn‚Äôt?

We used WCP belt and ThriftyBot belt for our elevators (although they‚Äôre practically the same, they have the same spec, just different logos on the belts), and neither failed in any capacity. I have not seen a belt be the failing point for an elevator this season from any team.

As for elevator design, we stole @Eliot Belted Continuous Elevator with a few modifications

We used WCP Bearing Blocks instead of REV

Kraken X60s instead of NEOs

5:1 MAXPlanetary Gearing

nuclearnerd:

Our team values reliability

Our elevator did not fail once in competition over the course of four district events plus worlds

posts.name: Ohad
posts.cooked: ill be honest, i dont know what youre looking for. i will say that in my experience getting dyneema products from reliable sources is hellish and for most applications kevlar rope is perfectly good

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: While I‚Äôm not super familiar with all the work that went into it, our robot from this year had a pretty simple continuous elevator with dyneema rope. You could probably find out more about it in our CAD Release but we basically have three winches on one shaft, two for ascent and one for descent. The ascent ropes originate on the winches and are rigged through pulleys placed on each elevator stage. The ropes are tied off on ratchets in the innermost stage to make it easier to maintain rope tension. The descent rope is placed on the middle winch and is connected to a small knob on the bottom of the top stage of the elevator.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
Jimmyy:

This is the first I have ever heard about a stripped belt in an elevator

A team we‚Äôre close to (I won‚Äôt speak for them) stripped one of their elevator belts the day before DCMP , requiring some heroics to find a replacement.

Then, at Houston CMP , the pit announcers put the call out for a ‚Äúspare 30 ft length of HTD belt‚Äù at least twice during the event, so clearly other teams had issues too.

I‚Äôm guessing pulley diameter and belt tension are important to keep the loads spread over several teeth, but I‚Äôm not sure what one needs to do to prevent failure.  That‚Äôs why I asked.
